sen.j: 膾（なます）は、魚介類や野菜類、果物類を細く（あるいは薄く）切ったものを、酢を基本にした調味料で和えた料理。
sen.e: Namasu is the dish made by thinly cutting (or slicing) sea foods, vegetables or fruits and dressing them with seasoning materials based mainly on vinegar.
Namasu is the dish made by thinly cutting (or slicing) sea foods, vegetables or fruits and dressing them with seasoning materials based mainly on vinegar.
Namasu is the dish made by thinly cutting (or slicing) sea foods, vegetables or fruits and dressing them with seasoning materials based mainly on vinegar.

sen.j: 正月の縁起物としても食される。
sen.e: It is also eaten as a lucky charm in the New Year.
It is also eaten as a lucky charm in the New Year.
It is also eaten as a lucky charm in the New Year.

sen.j: 日本の膾は独自に発生、発達したものである。
sen.e: Namasu in Japan emerged and developed in its own right.
Namasu in Japan emerged and developed in its own right.
Namasu in Japan emerged and developed in its own right.

sen.j: 日本でも古くは「なます」と言えばこの「膾」を意味していたが、院政期以降、魚介類や野菜を刻み調味料を合わせて食す料理である「和え物」と同一視されるようになった。
sen.e: "なます, namasu" in old Japan meant this "namasu, 膾," but after "Insei" period (period of the government by a retired emperor) it was identified with "aemono" which is the dish made by chopping sea foods or vegetables, dressing them with flavoring materials.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: "なます, namasu" in old Japan meant this "namasu, 膾," but after "Insei" period (period of the government by a retired emperor) it was identified with "aemono" which is the dish made by chopping sea foods or vegetables, dressing them with flavoring materials.

なます, namasu' in old Japan meant this 'namasu, 膾,' but after "Insei" period (period of the government by a retired emperor) it was identified with 'aemono' which is the dish made by chopping sea foods or vegetables, dressing them with flavoring materials.
sen.cmt: 原文で｢｣の部分を' 'にしました。

sen.j: 後には野菜だけを用いた「精進なます」のようなものも生じた。
sen.e: And later, something like "shojin namasu" (dish of only vegetables seasoned in vinegar) appeared.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: And later, something resembling "shojin namasu" (dish of only vegetables seasoned in vinegar) appeared.
And later, something resembling 'shojin namasu' (dish of only vegetables seasoned in vinegar) appeared.

sen.j: 現在「なます」の調味料として用いられるものとしては、甘酢、二杯酢、三杯酢、ゆず酢、たで酢などがあるが、古くは煎り酒（鰹節、梅干、酒、水、溜まりを合わせて煮詰めたもの）なども用いられた。
sen.e: At present, the seasoning materials used for "namasu" are sweet vinegar, "nihaizu" (vinegar and soy sauce mixed in roughly equal proportions), "sanbaizu" (vinegar, soy sauce and mirin (or sugar) mixed in roughly equal proportions), Japanese citron vinegar, "tadesu" (vinegar with waterpepper) and so on, but traditionally boiled-down sake (made by mixing dried bonito, Japanes apricot, sake, water and soy sauce and boiling them down) and so on were also used.

At present, the seasoning materials used for "namasu" are sweet vinegar, "nihaizu" (vinegar and soy sauce mixed in roughly equal proportions), "sanbaizu" (vinegar, soy sauce and mirin (or sugar) mixed in roughly equal proportions), Japanese citron vinegar, "tadesu" (vinegar with waterpepper) and so on, but traditionally boiled-down sake (made by mixing dried bonito, Japanes apricot, sake, water and soy sauce and boiling them down) and so on were also used.

At present, the seasoning materials used for 'namasu' are sweet vinegar, "nihaizu" (vinegar and soy sauce mixed in roughly equal proportions), "sanbaizu" (vinegar, soy sauce and mirin (or sugar) mixed in roughly equal proportions), Japanese citron vinegar, "tadesu" (vinegar with water pepper) and so on, but traditionally boiled-down sake (made by mixing dried bonito, Japanese apricot, sake, water and soy sauce and boiling them down) and so on were also used.
sen.cmt: 原文で｢｣の部分を' 'にしました。waterpepperをwater pepperに変更しました。JapanesをJapaneseに変更しました。

sen.j: 正月の御節料理としては、ごく細く切ったダイコンとニンジンを甘酢で漬け、ユズの皮で香りをつけた紅白膾（こうはくなます）が用いられることが多い。
sen.e: As osechi food (special food for New Years in Japan), "kohaku-namasu" is often used, which is made by slicing "daikon" (Japanese radish) and carrot, marinating them with sweet vinegar and seasoning them with a flavor of Japanese lemon peel.

As osechi food (special food for New Years in Japan), "kohaku-namasu" is often used, which is made by slicing "daikon" (Japanese radish) and carrot, marinating them with sweet vinegar and seasoning them with a flavor of Japanese lemon peel.

As osechi food (special food for New Years in Japan), "kohaku-namasu" is often used, which is made by slicing "daikon" (Japanese radish) and carrot, marinating them with sweet vinegar and seasoning them with a flavor of Japanese lemon peel.
sen.cmt: 余分なスペースを除去しました。

sen.j: これは繊切りのダイコンとニンジンを、縁起の良いとされる紅白の水引に見立てたもの。
sen.e: Here, daikon and carrot are regarded as red and white "mizuhiki" (an ancient applied art of tying various knots of special cords) which is said to be a good omen.
Here, daikon and carrot are regarded as red and white "mizuhiki" (an ancient applied art of tying various knots of special cords) which is said to be a good omen.
Here, daikon and carrot are regarded as red and white "mizuhiki" (an ancient applied art of tying various knots of special cords) which is said to be a good omen.

sen.j: 赤と白を源氏と平家の旗に見立て、源平膾（げんぺいなます）とも呼ばれる。
sen.e: The red and white are regarded as the flags of Genji and Heike and also called "genpei-namasu."
The red and white are regarded as the flags of Genji and Heike and also called "genpei-namasu."
The red and white are regarded as the flags of Genji and Heike and also called "genpei-namasu."

sen.j: 魚介類や野菜類を酢味噌で和えた料理である「ぬた」も膾の一種である。
sen.e: "Nuta" which is the dish made by seasoning sea foods or vegetables with vinegared miso is also a kind of namasu.
"Nuta" which is the dish made by seasoning sea foods or vegetables with vinegared miso is also a kind of namasu.
"Nuta" which is the dish made by seasoning sea foods or vegetables with vinegared miso is also a kind of namasu.

sen.j: 紅白膾の作り方
sen.e: How to make the kohaku-namasu
How to make the kohaku-namasu
How to make the kohaku-namasu

sen.j: ダイコンとニンジンを長さ5cmほどのごく細い繊切りにする。
sen.e: Shred daikon and carrot in five centimeters long.
Shred daikon and carrot in five centimeters long.
Shred daikon and carrot in five centimeters long.

sen.j: 切る前に皮を剥く方法もある。
sen.e: Before shredding them, you can peel them.
Before shredding them, you can peel them.
Before shredding them, you can peel them.

sen.j: 切ったダイコンとニンジンに塩をふり、しんなりしたら固く絞って水気をとる。
sen.e: Salt the shredded daikon and carrot and when they are tender, wring them dry.
Salt the shredded daikon and carrot and when they are tender, wring them dry.
Salt the shredded daikon and carrot and when they are tender, wring them dry.

sen.j: この際、ダイコンとニンジンを別に漬けたり、重石をのせて漬ける方法もある。
sen.e: On this occasion, you can pickle daikon and carrot separately or pickle by pressing them under a heavy stone.
On this occasion, you can pickle daikon and carrot separately or pickle by pressing them under a heavy stone.
On this occasion, you can pickle daikon and carrot separately or pickle by pressing them under a heavy stone.

sen.j: 酢、砂糖（食塩、水を入れる方法もある）を混ぜて、鷹の爪と共に漬ける。
sen.e: Mix them with vinegar and sugar (you can put salt and water) and pickle them with red peppers.
Mix them with vinegar and sugar (alternatively you can use salt and water) and pickle them with red peppers.
Mix them with vinegar and sugar (alternatively you can use salt and water) and pickle them with red peppers.

sen.j: （まず半量で漬けてから水気を切り、二度漬けする方法もある）
sen.e: (Pickle the half of them firstly and wring it dry and you can pickle them again.)
(Firstly, pickle half of them, wring them dry and if desired you can pickle them again.)
sen.cmt: Began sentence with "firstly", added "if desired" to read more smoothly.
sen.e: (Firstly, pickle half of them, wring them dry and if desired you can pickle them again.)

sen.j: ユズの皮を細かく切り混ぜる。
sen.e: Shred Japanese lemon peel and mix them.
Shred Japanese lemon peel and mix them.
Shred Japanese lemon peel and mix them.

sen.j: ことわざ・慣用句
sen.e: Proverbs and common expressions
Proverbs and common expressions
Proverbs and common expressions

sen.j: ことわざや慣用句での「膾」は、古代中国の切り分けた生肉や生魚による料理を意味することが多い。
sen.e: Namasu' in proverbs and common expressions often means the dishes which used the fillets of raw meat and raw fish in ancient China.
Namasu' in proverbs and common expressions often means the dishes which used the fillets of raw meat and raw fish in ancient China.
Namasu' in proverbs and common expressions often means the dishes which used the fillets of raw meat and raw fish in ancient China.

sen.j: 「羹（あつもの）に懲りて膾（なます）を吹く」
sen.e: Atsumono ni korite namasu wo fuku'
Atsumono ni korite namasu wo fuku'
Atsumono ni korite namasu wo fuku'
After burning the tongue or mouth by eating a hot "atsumono" (soup or soup dish) and disgusted, they eat even a cold namasu by blowing (cooling down by blowing) it.
After burning the tongue or mouth by eating a hot "atsumono" (soup or soup dish), they eat even a cold namasu by blowing on it.
sen.cmt: Wasn't sure about the use of "disgusted" here. Cut "cooling down by blowing" as it seemed unnecessary.
sen.e: After burning the tongue or mouth by eating a hot "atsumono" (soup or soup dish), they eat even a cold namasu by blowing on it.

sen.j: つまり、一度失敗した事に懲りて無益な用心をすること（「羹に懲りたる者、あえを吹く」と同意。
sen.e: This means that once failed and disgusted, they become uselessly careful ('Atsumono ni koritarumono, ae wo fuku' (Those who were disgusted with a hot soup blow a marinated food or sashimi) means the same).

This means that once failed and disgusted, they become uselessly careful ('Atsumono ni koritarumono, ae wo fuku' (Those who were disgusted with a hot soup blow a marinated food or sashimi) means the same).

This means that once failed and disgusted, they become uselessly careful ('Atsumono ni koritarumono, ae wo fuku' (Those who were disgusted with a hot soup blow a marinated food or sashimi) means the same).

sen.j: ”あえ”とはあえもの、刺身の意味）。
sen.e: "Ae" means an aemono or sashimi.
"Ae" means an aemono or sashimi.
"Ae" means an aemono or sashimi.

sen.j: 「人口に膾炙（かいしゃ）する」
sen.e: Jinko ni kaisha suru' (kaisha (膾炙), namasu and broiled meat are eaten by many people)
Jinko ni kaisha suru' (kaisha (膾炙), namasu and broiled meat are eaten by many people)
Jinko ni kaisha suru' (kaisha (膾炙), namasu and broiled meat are eaten by many people)

sen.j: - 膾と炙（あぶり肉、直火による焼き肉）はいずれも多くの人が喜んで食べることから、物事が多くの人の間で話題になることをいう。
sen.e: As many people like to eat '膾と炙' (namasu and "aburi" (broiled meat)), this means that some matters are spread and popular among many people.
As many people like to eat '膾と炙' (namasu and "aburi" (broiled meat)), this meant it spread and became popular among many people.
As many people like to eat '膾と炙' (namasu and "aburi" (broiled meat)), this meant it spread and became popular among many people.

sen.j: 「膾（なます）に叩く」
sen.e: Namasu ni tataku' (Beat namasu)
Namasu ni tataku' (Beat namasu)
Namasu ni tataku' (Beat namasu)

sen.j: - 膾は細かに切り刻むことから、転じて大勢で人を滅多打ちにすることを指す。
sen.e: As namasu is shredded, this figuratively means that a man is beaten violently by many people.
As namasu is shredded, this figuratively means that a man is beaten violently by many people.
As namasu is shredded, this figuratively means that a man is beaten violently by many people.

sen.j: 起源説等
sen.e: Origin and so on
Origin and so on
Origin and so on

sen.j: 「膾（音読みで「カイ」）」は本来、古代中国において、切り分けた獣肉に調味料を合わせて生食する料理を指した。
sen.e: "膾 ("kai" in a Chinese reading)" originally referred to the dish which was made by cutting the raw animal meat out and mixing it with seasonings.
"膾 ("kai" in a Chinese reading)" originally referred to the dish which was made by cutting the raw animal meat out and mixing it with seasonings.
膾 ('kai' in a Chinese reading)' originally referred to the dish which was made by cutting the raw animal meat out and mixing it with seasonings.

sen.j: 魚肉を用いて同様の調理をしたものは「鱠」、また「魚膾」ともいった。
sen.e: The dishes which were cooked similarly by using a fish meat were called namasu (鱠, 魚膾).
The dishes which were cooked similarly by using a fish meat were called namasu (鱠, 魚膾).
The dishes which were cooked similarly by using a fish meat were called 'namasu (鱠, 魚膾).'
sen.cmt: 原文で｢｣の部分を' 'にしました。

sen.j: 日本語「なます」の語源は不明であるが、「なましし（生肉）」「なますき（生切）」が転じたという説がある。
sen.e: The word origin of "namasu" in Japanese is unknown, but some say that "namashishi" (raw meat) or "namasuki" (raw cut) are the origin.
The word origin of "namasu" in Japanese is unknown, but some say that "namashishi" (raw meat) or "namasuki" (raw cut) are the origin.
The word origin of 'namasu' in Japanese is unknown, but some say that 'namashishi' (raw meat) or 'namasuki' (raw cut) are the origin.

sen.j: 一般には「生酢」と解されているが、先述したように、古くは調味料として必ずしも酢を用いるとは限らなかったので、民間語源の類であるという説がある。
sen.e: Generally speaking, namasu is interpreted as "生酢, namasu" (raw vinegar), but as mentioned before, originally vinegar was not always used as a seasoning and so some say that it is a sort of folk etymology.

Generally speaking, namasu is interpreted as "生酢, namasu" (raw vinegar), but as mentioned before, originally vinegar was not always used as a seasoning and so some say that it is a sort of folk etymology.

Generally speaking, namasu is interpreted as '生酢, namasu' (raw vinegar), but as mentioned before, originally vinegar was not always used as a seasoning and so some say that it is a sort of folk etymology.

sen.j: 朝鮮半島では、「膾」または「鱠」を「フェ」と呼ぶ。
sen.e: In Korean Peninsula, "膾 or 鱠, namasu" is called "fue."
In Korean Peninsula, "膾 or 鱠, namasu" is called "fue."
In Korean Peninsula, '膾 or 鱠, namasu' is called 'fue.'

sen.j: フェには刺身状の料理が含まれる。
sen.e: Fue includes the dishes like sashimi.
Fue includes the dishes like sashimi.
Fue includes the dishes like sashimi.

sen.j: 例えばユッケは「肉膾」と書き、膾の一種とされる。
sen.e: For example, "yukke" (raw meat food) is spelled as "肉膾" (meat namasu) and is regarded as a kind of namasu.
For example, "yukke" (raw meat food) is spelled as "肉膾" (meat namasu) and is regarded as a kind of namasu.
For example, 'yukke' (raw meat food) is spelled as '肉膾' (meat namasu) and is regarded as a kind of namasu.

sen.j: また素材は生肉や生魚とは限らず、家畜の内臓に火を通して野菜類と和えたフェもある。
sen.e: Also, the materials are not always raw fish or raw meat and some fues are made by heating the inner parts of farm animals and mixing them with vegetables.
Also, the materials are not always raw fish or raw meat and some fues are made by heating the innards of farm animals and mixing them with vegetables.
